Week 11. July 21

polynomial time reduction

it is more convenient to restrict to decision problem so that every problem has same output format. if we know how to solve decision version of the problem in polynomial time, then we can use the decision algorithm as blackbox/subroutine to solve the the search version of problem in polynomial time.

eg. find a max bipartite matching.

  1. decision version: does G have a matching of size at least k?
  2. use binary search on all k to find an optimal value k
  3. try deleting an edge e from G. does G-e have a matching of size at least k?
    1. if yes: delete e
    2. if no: keep e and try other edge
    3. (reduces to |E| decision problems)
  4. what is left is the matching

defn. a decision problem A is polynomial time reducible to decision problem B if there exists a polynomial time algorithm F that maps any input instance IAI_AIA​ of A into an input instance IBI_BIB​ of B such that IAI_AIA​ is a YES-instance of problem A iff IBI_BIB​ is a YES-instance of problem B. we write A≤pBA\leq_p BA≤p​B when such a polynomial time reduction exists, saying A is not more difficult than B in terms of polynomial time solvability.

algo (solving problem A by reduction):

  1. use reduction algorithm F to transform IAI_AIA​ into IBI_BIB​
  2. return algB(IB)\texttt{alg}_B(I_B)algB​(IB​)

runtime: F maps IAI_AIA​ to IBI_BIB​ in p(∣IA∣)p(|I_A|)p(∣IA​∣), alg\texttt{alg}alg solves IBI_BIB​ in q(∣IB∣)q(|I_B|)q(∣IB​∣). total q(p(∣IA∣))q(p(|I_A|))q(p(∣IA​∣)).

corollary. if A cannot be solved in polynomial time, then B cannot be solved in polynomial time.

  • by our current knowledge, we know almost nothing about proving a problem cannot be solved in polynomial time, so we cannot draw such strong conclusion.

prop. (transitivity) if A≤pBA\leq_p BA≤p​B and B≤pCB\leq_p CB≤p​C, then A≤pCA\leq_p CA≤p​C.
proof. transform IAI_AIA​ to IBI_BIB​ then to ICI_CIC​. □\square□

three problems

maximum clique (Clique):

defn. a subset S⊆VS\subseteq VS⊆V is a clique if uv∈Euv\in Euv∈E for all u,v∈Su,v\in Su,v∈S.

decision version: given graph G=(V,E), is there a clique with at least k vertices?

maximum independent set (IS):

decision version: given graph G=(V,E), is there an independent set with at least k vertices?

minimum vertex cover (VC):

decision version: given graph G=(V,E), is there a vertex cover with at most k vertices?

prop. Clique≤pIS\texttt{Clique}\leq_p\texttt{IS}Clique≤p​IS and IS≤pClique\texttt{IS}\leq_p\texttt{Clique}IS≤p​Clique.
proof.

  • Clique≤pIS\texttt{Clique}\leq_p\texttt{IS}Clique≤p​IS: define reduction F((G,k))=(G‾,k)F((G,k))=(\overline{G},k)F((G,k))=(G,k) where G‾=(V,E‾)\overline{G}=(V,\overline{E})G=(V,E) where E‾={uv:uv∉E}\overline{E}=\{uv:uv\notin E\}E={uv:uv∈/E}. by definition, G has a clique of size at least k iff G‾\overline{G}G has an independent set of size at least k.
  • IS≤pClique\texttt{IS}\leq_p\texttt{Clique}IS≤p​Clique: same as above. □\square□

prop. VC≤pIS\texttt{VC}\leq_p\texttt{IS}VC≤p​IS and IS≤pVC\texttt{IS}\leq_p\texttt{VC}IS≤p​VC
proof.

  • observation. in G=(V,E), a subset S⊆VS\subseteq VS⊆V is a vertex cover iff V−SV-SV−S is an independent set.
    • S being vertex cover means all edges will have one endpoint in S. for V-S, there cannot be edges with both endponts in V-S because if there were, it would appear in S.
  • VC≤pIS\texttt{VC}\leq_p\texttt{IS}VC≤p​IS: define reduction F((G,k))=(G,∣V∣−k)F((G,k))=(G,|V|-k)F((G,k))=(G,∣V∣−k). we claim G has a vertex cover of size at most k iff G has an independent set of size at least |V|-k.
  • IS≤pVC\texttt{IS}\leq_p\texttt{VC}IS≤p​VC: same as above. □\square□

so all three problems are equivalent in terms of polynomial time solvability.

three more problems

hamiltonian cycle (HC):

defn. a cycle is hamiltonian if it touches every vertex exactly once.

decision version: given graph G=(V,E), does G have a hamiltonian cycle?

hamiltonian path (HP):

defn. a path is hamiltonian if it touches every vertex exactly once.

decision version: given graph G=(V,E), does G have a hamiltonian path?

traveling salesman problem (TSP):

decision version: given graph G=(V,E) with an length lel_ele​ for each edge e∈Ee\in Ee∈E, is there a hamiltonian cycle with total length at most LLL?

prop. HP≤pHC\mathtt{HP}\leq_p\texttt{HC}HP≤p​HC.
proof. define reduction F(G(V,E))=G′(V∪{s},E∪{sv:v∈V})F(_G(V,E))=_{G'}(V\cup\{s\},E\cup\{sv:v\in V\})F(G​(V,E))=G′​(V∪{s},E∪{sv:v∈V}), where s is an additional vertex that goes to every existing vertex. claim G has a HP iff G' has a HC.

  • if G has HP that ends at a,ba,ba,b, then in G', connect av,bvav,bvav,bv we have a HC.
  • if G' has HC, then in G, delete the two edges connecting sss we have a HP. □\square□

prop. HC≤pHP\mathtt{HC}\leq_p\texttt{HP}HC≤p​HP
proof. define reduction F(G(V,E))=G′(V∪{x′,t1,t2},E∪{x′v:v∈N(x)}∪{t1x′,t2x})F(_G(V,E))=_{G'}(V\cup\{x',t_1,t_2\},E\cup\{x'v:v\in N(x)\}\cup\{t_1x',t_2x\})F(G​(V,E))=G′​(V∪{x′,t1​,t2​},E∪{x′v:v∈N(x)}∪{t1​x′,t2​x}) where x∈Vx\in Vx∈V is arbitrary. claim G has a HC iff G' has a HP.

  • if G has a HC x...yxx...yxx...yx that visits x, then in G', path t2[x...y]x′t1t_2[x...y]x't_1t2​[x...y]x′t1​ is a HP, where we break the cycle at the edge yxyxyx.
  • if G' has a HP, then it must be t2x...yx′t1t_2x...yx't_1t2​x...yx′t1​ as t1,t2t_1,t_2t1​,t2​ has degree 1. then in G, we can use the edge yxyxyx (which must exist as yx′yx'yx′ exists, and x′x'x′ is a clone of xxx) to close the cycle. □\square□

prop. HC≤pTSP\texttt{HC}\leq_p\texttt{TSP}HC≤p​TSP.
proof. define transform F(G(V,E))=G′(V,V2)F(_G(V,E))=_{G'}(V,V^2)F(G​(V,E))=G′​(V,V2) such that G′G'G′ is complete graph, and luv=1 ∀uv∈E,luv=2 ∀uv∉El_{uv}=1\,\forall uv\in E,l_{uv}=2\,\forall uv\notin Eluv​=1∀uv∈E,luv​=2∀uv∈/E. claim G has a HC iff G' has a HC of total length at most ∣V∣|V|∣V∣. □\square□

note (in hw) also need to show these transformations are done in polynomial time.

remark. it is not clear how to reduce TSP to HC.

3-satisfiability

given n boolean variables (xi)i=1n(x_i)_{i=1}^n(xi​)i=1n​ which can be either True or False, and a formula in conjunctive normal form (CNF) where it is an AND of the clauses where each clause is an OR of the literals where a literal is either xix_ixi​ or xi‾\overline{x_i}xi​​.

(x1∨x2∨x3‾)∧(x2‾∨x3∨x4‾)∧(x1‾∨x3‾∨x4)∧(x2‾∨x3)(x_1\lor x_2\lor \overline{x_3})\land(\overline{x_2} \lor x_3 \lor \overline{x_4})\land(\overline{x_1}\lor \overline{x_3}\lor x_4)\land(\overline{x_2}\lor x_3) (x1​∨x2​∨x3​​)∧(x2​​∨x3​∨x4​​)∧(x1​​∨x3​​∨x4​)∧(x2​​∨x3​)

if each clause has at most 3 literals, is there a truth assignment to the variables that satisfies all the clauses?

theorem. 3SAT≤pIS\texttt{3SAT}\leq_p\texttt{IS}3SAT≤p​IS.
proof. given a 3SAT formula, we would like to construct a graph G so that the formula is satisfiable iff the graph has an independent set of size m where m is the number of clauses. for each clause, we connect at most three vertices corresponding to the literals (so single vertex/pair/triangle) (ensure in each clause we satisfy one literal). we also connect vertices xixi‾x_i\overline{x_i}xi​xi​​ (to prevent both of them appearing in the independent set at same time).

  • suppose we have a satisfying assignment (xi)i(x_i)_i(xi​)i​, then if xix_ixi​ is True, we put xix_ixi​ in IS, if xix_ixi​ is False, we put xi‾\overline{x_i}xi​​ in IS. since we pick exactly one literal from each clause, we do not violate first type of edges. since we pick either xix_ixi​ or xi‾\overline{x_i}xi​​, we do not violate second type of edges. now we have a set of m vertices.
  • suppose we have an IS of size m. because of second type, we will not have both xi,xi‾x_i,\overline{x_i}xi​,xi​​, so for each vertex in G, if xix_ixi​ is in IS, then xix_ixi​ = True; if xi‾\overline{x_i}xi​​ is in IS, then xix_ixi​ = False; if both not in IS, then xix_ixi​ is arbitrary. because of the first type of edges, each clause has at most 1 vertex in the IS. because there are m clauses, each vertex in IS must come from one clause. so all clauses are satisfied. □\square□

remark. it is not important how many literals in a clause.

NP-completeness

it is not easy to compare every pairs (O(n^2)) of problems to see if they can be reduced to each other. we can identify the 'hardest' problems in a large class of problems.

a general feature of problems is that there is a short 'proof/solution' of a YES-instance - it is easier to verify.

defn. for a problem X, each input instance of X is represented by a binary string s. a problem X is in the class NP if there is a polynomial time verification algorithm BXB_XBX​ s.t. the input s is a YES-instance iff there is a proof t which is a binary string of length poly(∣s∣)\mathrm{poly}(|s|)poly(∣s∣) so that BX(s,t)B_X(s,t)BX​(s,t) returns YES.

  • in most cases, t is simply a solution and BXB_XBX​ is an efficient algo to check if t is indeed a solution.
input s --> +----+
            | Bx | --> YES/NO
proof t --> +----+

eg. show vertex cover is in NP.
we are given graph G and an integer k. we encode (G, k) into a binary string s, and t into a binary string of S⊆VS\subseteq VS⊆V. let BXB_XBX​ be algo that takes s and t as input and checks if every edge is covered by SSS with size <= k. then BXB_XBX​ says yes if S is vertex of size <= k, and says NO if t does not correspond to a vertex cover of size <= k. □\square□

eg. show 3SAT is in NP.
we are given a truth assignment (size <= n). algo: check if it is satisfying (runtime O(m)) where m is number of clauses. iff is clear. □\square□

remark. Clique, IS, HC, HP, subset-sum are all in NP.

remark. (non-HC) we do not know a short proof how to show graph has no HC.

defn. X is in co-NP if there is short proof and an efficient verification for NO-instances.

eg. bipartite matching (at most size k) is in both NP and co-NP.
for NO-instances (asking does G have graph has no matching >= k?), by konig, it is the same a asking 'whether G has vertex cover of size < k?', which is easy to check.

remark. it is common belief NP≠co−NP\mathrm{NP}\neq\mathrm{co-NP}NP=co−NP.

remark. P⊆NP\mathrm{P}\subseteq\mathrm{NP}P⊆NP. if problem can be solved in poly time, it is trivially in NP (do not even need another t and BXB_XBX​).

remark. our NP definition is equivalent to saying "NP is class of problems solvable by a non-deterministic turing machine in poly time".

remark. it is common belief P≠NP\mathrm{P}\neq\mathrm{NP}P=NP.

defn. a problem X∈NPX\in\mathrm{NP}X∈NP is NP-complete if Y≤pXY\leq_p XY≤p​X for all Y∈NPY\in\mathrm{NP}Y∈NP.

prop. P=NP iff an NP-complete problem can be solved in polynomial time.

to prove a problem X is NP-complete, we first show X is NP, then find an NP-complete problem Y show Y≤pXY\leq_p XY≤p​X. (common mistake is showing X <=p Y)

Week 12. July 28

cook-levin theorem

we introduce an intermediate problem to show 3SAT is NP-complete.

circuit-SAT: given a circuit with AND/OR/NOT gates, some known input gates and some unknown input gates, assuming input circuit is DAG, and each AND/OR gate has only two incoming edges.. is there a truth assignment on the unknown input gates so that the output is True?

theorem. circuit-SAT is NP-complete.
pf. we want to show for all NP problem X we have X≤pCircuit-SATX\leq_p\texttt{Circuit-SAT}X≤p​Circuit-SAT. we start from the definition of NP (algorithm satisfaction: there exists a verification program that runs in poly time), and try to use a poly-time compiler to turn the verification algo into a circuit of poly size so that the circuit says YES if given input s and proof t is for YES instances, and NO if the problem's answer is NO no matter what proof is given. then input s is a YES-instance iff there is a satisfying assignment for Circuit-SAT. □\square□

theorem. Circuit-SAT≤p3-SAT\texttt{Circuit-SAT}\leq_p\texttt{3-SAT}Circuit-SAT≤p​3-SAT.
pf. given circuit of n gates, we will construct a 3SAT formula with O(n) variables so that circuit is satisfiable iff the formula is satisfiable.:

  • if we have a gate True, then we make a clause aaa
    true --> a
  • if we have a gate False, then we make a clause b‾\overline{b}b
    false --> b
  • if we have a NOT gate, then we make two clauses a↔b‾=(a‾∨b‾)∧(a∨b)a\leftrightarrow\overline{b}=(\overline{a}\lor\overline{b})\land(a\lor b)a↔b=(a∨b)∧(a∨b)
    a --> NOT --> b
  • if we have an AND gate, then we make (a∧b)↔c=(a‾∨b‾∨c)∧(a∨c‾)∧(b∨c‾)(a\land b)\leftrightarrow c=(\overline{a}\lor\overline{b}\lor c)\land(a\lor\overline{c})\land(b\lor\overline{c})(a∧b)↔c=(a∨b∨c)∧(a∨c)∧(b∨c)
    a -->
       AND --> c
b -->
  • if we have an OR gate, then we make (a∨b)↔c=(a∨b∨c‾)∧(a‾∨c)∧(b‾∨c)(a\lor b)\leftrightarrow c=(a\lor b\lor \overline{c})\land(\overline{a}\lor c)\land(\overline{b}\lor c)(a∨b)↔c=(a∨b∨c)∧(a∨c)∧(b∨c)
    a -->
       OR --> c
b -->

it is clear we can turn the circuit into a 3SAT formula in poly time in terms of size of circuit (# of gates/edges). plugging in x, y, z into the circuit, and simulate the circuit behavior regarding gates, then the resultant variables satisfy the formula too. if there is assignment of the formula, plugging them into the circuit will make the circuit happy as well. □\square□

theorem. (cook-levin) 3-SAT is NP-complete.

hamiltonian cycle

defn. a directed cycle is a hamiltonian cycle if it touches every vertex exactly once.

directed hamiltonian cycle (DHC): given directed graph G=(V,E), does G has a DHC?

theorem. DHC is NP-complete.
proof. it is easy to check DHC is in NP. we now will show 3SAT≤pDHC\texttt{3SAT}\leq_p\texttt{DHC}3SAT≤p​DHC, ie given a 3SAT formula with n variables (xi)i=1n(x_i)_{i=1}^n(xi​)i=1n​ and m clauses (Ci)i=1m(C_i)_{i=1}^m(Ci​)i=1m​, we would like to construct a directed graph G so that formula is satisfiable iff G has a DHC. we create a long 'two-way' path for each variable, so that going the path from left to right corresponds to setting variable to True, while from right to left corresponds to setting it to False.

now a hamilton cycle in G has one-to-one correspondence with an assignment. now we want to add clause structures so that only satisfying assignments 'survive'. for each clause, we create a separate vertex. depending on whether literal is negated, we assign different directions for edges that go to the clause vertex (thus forcing the left/right direction of each PiP_iPi​). note clause vertex only has edges to the portions reserved for the clause.

  • if we have a satisfying assignment, then xi=Tx_i=Txi​=T means we go from left to right on PiP_iPi​, and xi=Fx_i=Fxi​=F means going from right to left. for each clause CaC_aCa​, one literal is satisfied xjx_jxj​, we can 'detour' to visit CaC_aCa​ in the path PjP_jPj​, and keep going forward (one variable may get multiple clauses, and variable might get no clauses). then every vertex is visited exactly once.
  • if we have a DHC. we want to show it behaves exactly as we wanted, ie we do not have cycles that jumps out of certain PiP_iPi​ at vvv and goes to some CaC_aCa​, and jumps to some other PjP_jPj​. if jump happens, then we the next edge to vvv becomes a dead end (thus once we go to a clause, we must come back immediately). since every clause is visited and each variable/path foes in the correct direction, we have a satisfying assignment with all clauses satisfied. □\square□

prop. DHC≤pHC\texttt{DHC}\leq_p\texttt{HC}DHC≤p​HC.
proof. given input directed graph G, we use a length 3 path to simulate a directed edge. for each vertex vvv in G, we create 3 vertices vin,vmid,voutv_{\textrm{in}},v_\textrm{mid},v_\textrm{out}vin​,vmid​,vout​ connected with two middle edges, and vinv_\textrm{in}vin​ has original in-edges in G, voutv_\textrm{out}vout​ has out-edges. we claim G has a DHC iff G' has a HC.

it is clear if G has a DHC, we can follow it in G' to form a HC. suppose we have a HC in G' and it starts from aina_\textrm{in}ain​, then must goto amida_\textrm{mid}amid​, then to aouta_\textrm{out}aout​, then go to some other binb_\textrm{in}bin​, .... if we shrink each three vertex we get a DHC in G. (having mid vertex amida_\textrm{mid}amid​ forces a path to go to it onces it touches some in vertex aina_\textrm{in}ain​, otherwise it may just leave if some other coutc_\textrm{out}cout​ goes to aina_\textrm{in}ain​, which is not what we want it to behave) □\square□

corollary. HC is NP-complete.

graph coloring

given undirected graph G=(V,E) and positive integer k, is it possible to use k colors to color all vertices so that every vertex receives one vertex and any two adjacent vertices receive different colors?

  • when k=1, it is possible iff graph has no edges
  • when k=2, it is possible iff graph is bipartite

theorem. 3-coloring is NP-complete.
proof. it is easy to check 3-coloring is in NP. we want to show 3SAT≤p3-coloring\texttt{3SAT}\leq_p\texttt{3-coloring}3SAT≤p​3-coloring, ie given a 3SAT formula with n variables (xi)i=1n(x_i)_{i=1}^n(xi​)i=1n​ and m clauses (Ci)i=1m(C_i)_{i=1}^m(Ci​)i=1m​, we would like to construct a graph G so that formula is satisfiable iff G is 3-colorable. we associate True and False as two colors. for each variable xix_ixi​, we create two vertices vi,vi‾v_i,\overline{v_i}vi​,vi​​ and add an edge between them so they get different colors. to enforce they get True/False colors, we connect every literal vertex to a common vertex called base vertex colored using color B.

so there is 1-1 correspondence between truth assignments and the 3-colorings.

we now involve clauses so that only satisfying assignments remain. we can use a 'gadget' to connect to the three variables in the clause so that there is a 3-coloring for the gadget iff at least one of them gets the color T. say we have clause (x1∪x2‾∪x3)(x_1\cup\overline{x_2}\cup x_3)(x1​∪x2​​∪x3​), after trail-and-error, we can attach the following gadget to the base graph:

vertices with no labels mean they are added only for this clause. then suppose all v1,v2‾,v3v_1,\overline{v_2},v_3v1​,v2​​,v3​ are colored F => meaning clause is not satisfied. then all colors of vertices are forced, we cannot color the top node using any color. if any of them is colored T, then the top vertex can be colored using the 3 colors (check).

  • if there is a satisfying assignment. for each variable xix_ixi​, if it is True, then we color viv_ivi​ = T and vi‾\overline{v_i}vi​​ = F; otherwise if it is False, we color viv_ivi​ = F and vi‾\overline{v_i}vi​​ = T. it is clear this is a valid coloring for the initial base graph (without gadgets). since assignment is satisfying, each clause gets at least one of the 3 'input' set to be T, and so it can be extended to a 3-coloring in the gadget.
  • if there is a 3-coloring of graph, then for each gadget, there is at least one 'input' of the gadget with color T. by the initial base graph, the coloring on (vi,vi‾)i=1n(v_i,\overline{v_i})_{i=1}^n(vi​,vi​​)i=1n​ must be consistent with truth assignment, so we can use the coloring to get a truth assignment that satisfies all clauses. □\square□

3-dimensional matching

given disjoint sets X, Y, Z each of size n, a set T⊆X×Y×ZT\subseteq X\times Y\times ZT⊆X×Y×Z. does there exist a subset of n disjoint triples in T (cover every element exactly once)?

a subset of n disjoint triples is called perfect 3d-matching.

x1 -- y1 -- z1
x2 -- y2 -- z2
x3 -- y3 -- z3

T={(x1,y1,z1),(x2,y2,z2),(x3,y3,z3)}

theorem. 3DM is NP-complete.
proof. it is easy to check 3DM is in NP. we want to show 3SAT≤p3DM\texttt{3SAT}\leq_p\texttt{3DM}3SAT≤p​3DM, ie given 3SAT formula with n variables (xi)i=1n(x_i)_{i=1}^n(xi​)i=1n​ and m clauses (Ci)i=1m(C_i)_{i=1}^m(Ci​)i=1m​, we would like to construct a 3DM instance (hypergraph) so that the formula is satisfiable iff there is a perfect 3d-matching. for each variable vvv, we create (xi)i=1m,(yi)i=1m,(zi)i=12m(x_i)_{i=1}^m,(y_i)_{i=1}^m,(z_i)_{i=1}^{2m}(xi​)i=1m​,(yi​)i=1m​,(zi​)i=12m​ enclosed in a gadget. the x,yx,yx,y's are private to this variable and zzz's might be open. we have to cover a triple at a time and we try to cover all private nodes (cores).

if three nodes are in a circle, it means such combination is possible (in T). note we have 2m zzz's as we reserve 2 zzz's for each clause, half of them is used to cover triples and half is open.

so we have 1-1 one correspondence between the value of a variable and how private nodes are covered. we have n such flowers corresponding to n variables.

we now add some clause structure to the 3dm instance so that only satisfying assignments survive. the clause structure for each clause contains xc,ycx_c,y_cxc​,yc​ and can contain a free zzz from the existing flowers, reserved for that clause.

]

at this point we have totally 2mn tips, # of tips covered by clauses is m. we have (2n-1)m tips left to cover (how about already-covered zzz's in each variable? should you minus mn?). we add this number of 'dummy' clauses which can form triples connecting two dummy nodes and one free zzz like they were clauses.

  • if we have satisfying assignment, for each variable xix_ixi​, if it is True, in gadget i we leave odd tips open, if it is False, we leave even tips open. for each clause satisfied by some literal xjx_jxj​, that clause covers the free zzz in that gadget i. for remaining tips, the dummy ones can cover them, so we have perfect 3d-matching.
  • if we have perfect 3d-matching. in each gadget, either all even tips are open (False) or all odd tips are open (True). because matching is full, for each clause, their clause elements must be covered, and it contains a zzz meaning a value of variable depending on the parity of the zzz, so we have a satisfying assignment. □\square□

subset sum

given n positive integers (ai)i=1n(a_i)_{i=1}^n(ai​)i=1n​ and an integer K, does there exist a subset S⊆[n]S\subseteq[n]S⊆[n] with ∑i∈Sai=K\sum_{i\in S}a_i=K∑i∈S​ai​=K?

theorem. Subset-Sum is NP-complete.
proof. it is easy to check it is in NP. we want to show 3DM≤pSubset-Sum\texttt{3DM}\leq_p\texttt{Subset-Sum}3DM≤p​Subset-Sum., ie given 3DM instance, we would like to construct a subset-sum instance so that there is perfect 3d-matching iff there is subset of certain sum K. we naturally represent each triple as a vector: if node is used in a triple, in the vector it has 1 else 0.

vector Subset-Sum: given a set of n 0-1 vectors, does there exist a subset of vectors that sum to 1\mathbf{1}1? we can see there is a perfect 3DM iff there is a subset of vectors summing to 1\mathbf{1}1. so this vector Subset-Sum is also NP-complete.

to turn this vector Subset-Sum into Subset-Sum, we map each 0-1 vector to a base (m+1)-numbers, then (xi,yi,zk)↦(m+1)i+(m+1)n+j+(m+1)2n+k(x_i,y_i,z_k)\mapsto(m+1)^i+(m+1)^{n+j}+(m+1)^{2n+k}(xi​,yi​,zk​)↦(m+1)i+(m+1)n+j+(m+1)2n+k, where m is number of available triples in 3DM (|T|).

  • if there exists a perfect 3DM, we can turn the matching into these numbers, then we have sum ∑l=13n(m+1)l\sum_{l=1}^{3n}(m+1)^l∑l=13n​(m+1)l.
  • if we have the subset of numbers, because the base (m+1) is large enough, each 'coordinate' records how many times an element is covered. to achieve sum K, each element must be covered exactly once, we have a perfect 3DM. □\square□

remark. to turn this vector Subset-Sum into Subset-Sum, we could interpret the 0-1 vector as the binary representation of a number, then (xi,yj,zk)↦2i+2n+j+22n+k(x_i,y_j,z_k)\mapsto 2^i+2^{n+j}+2^{2n+k}(xi​,yj​,zk​)↦2i+2n+j+22n+k.

  • if there exists a perfect 3DM, we can turn the matching into these numbers, then we have sum ∑l=13n2l\sum_{l=1}^{3n}2^l∑l=13n​2l (all 1's in binary).

but reverse is not true <~ carrying may happen eg. 01+01+01=11=01+10. so we need base m+1 to avoid this.

corollary. knapsack is NP-complete.

map

techniques for doing reductions:

  • specialization:
    • Subset-Sum≤pknapsack\texttt{Subset-Sum}\leq_p\texttt{knapsack}Subset-Sum≤p​knapsack
    • HC≤pTSP\texttt{HC}\leq_p\texttt{TSP}HC≤p​TSP
    • HP≤pBounded Degree Spanning Tree\texttt{HP}\leq_p\text{Bounded Degree Spanning Tree}HP≤p​Bounded Degree Spanning Tree (degree at max 2)
  • local replacement:
    • Circuit-SAT≤p3-SAT\texttt{Circuit-SAT}\leq_p\texttt{3-SAT}Circuit-SAT≤p​3-SAT
    • 3DM≤pvector Subset-Sum≤pSubset-Sum\texttt{3DM}\leq_p\texttt{vector Subset-Sum}\leq_p\texttt{Subset-Sum}3DM≤p​vector Subset-Sum≤p​Subset-Sum
    • DHC≤pHC\texttt{DHC}\leq_p\texttt{HC}DHC≤p​HC
  • gadget design:
    • 3SAT≤pDHC,3DM,3-coloring\texttt{3SAT}\leq_p\texttt{DHC},\texttt{3DM},\texttt{3-coloring}3SAT≤p​DHC,3DM,3-coloring

2 vs 3

  • 2SAT can be solved in poly time: xi∪xj=xi‾→xjx_i\cup x_j=\overline{x_i}\rightarrow x_jxi​∪xj​=xi​​→xj​, find strongly connected component
  • 2DM can be solved in poly time: perfect matching in bipartite graph
  • 2 coloring can be solved in poly time: check if graph is bipartite
